stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on enemy/NPC implementation for the Wild West content: integrating Zeina’s new animations/models (Dry Bones enemy behavior, a saloon piano NPC, and a cowboy Boshi dueling NPC), tuning AI/animation timing, and fixing in-game audio priority issues. He also discusses an unrevealed collaboration level (with Aeza) for a Course 14 sub-area, ongoing renderer performance concerns (new F3DEX being slow), and his tooling/hardware workflow (Project64 vs parallel launcher, EverDrive issues, interest in SummerCart64).
stream_context.significance_reason: Completes a full enemy implementation pass (Dry Bones) and outlines a key Wild West set-piece (Boshi duel) with accessibility-minded difficulty scaling, plus concrete technical/audio workflow fixes and collaboration dependencies (Aeza, Sauraen, Zeina).

findings.summary: Kaze is building an unrevealed collaboration level with Aeza: both are making levels intended to “double cash in” on a shared release/visibility moment; Kaze’s portion is a Course 14 sub-area but he avoids showing it on-stream yet.

For the Wild West Dry Bones, Kaze chooses a more “zombie-like” walk cycle and generally scales animation playback speed with the actor’s actual movement speed to keep motion believable across different speeds.

Kaze implements line-of-sight and distance checks for the Dry Bones chase state and uses different in-range vs out-of-range thresholds (hysteresis) to prevent rapid state/animation toggling when Mario hovers near the detection boundary.

Kaze tunes Dry Bones movement feel by adjusting acceleration/deceleration and view angle, and also adds a “memory” behavior: the enemy can remain in a pursuit/alert state briefly even when Mario moves behind it.

He adds footstep SFX synced to specific animation frames and discovers a sound-mixing issue where a Wild West barrel sound is monopolizing audio (muting other sounds). He fixes this by changing priority and falloff and creating a separate barrel sound action.

Kaze considers the Dry Bones enemy essentially “done” (core AI, animations, and collision behavior working). Remaining polish is deferred: a crumble SFX will be added later due to end-of-project sound-bank/space constraints.
He changes the crumble state to use a pushable collision instead of no-collision so the enemy still physically interacts with Mario/environment while collapsed, improving feel/readability.

Zeina’s art pipeline is central this stream: she provided the Dry Bones animations, a saloon “piano guy” NPC model, and a heavily-animated cowboy Boshi character; Kaze validates them in-game and sends assets back when ready to animate/fix.

While prepping the saloon piano NPC, Kaze optimizes textures/UVs for N64 constraints: he reduces texture usage (cutting mirrored/unused areas) to save memory, and troubleshoots rig issues (unweighted bones / multi-weight problems) during import.

Kaze outlines a Wild West Boshi “quick-draw duel” minigame: Boshi challenges Mario, explains rules via dialogue, then a countdown plus random delay leads to a “go” cue; both shoot (Boshi throws an egg; Mario shoots a cork gun).

To make the duel broadly beatable, Kaze plans adaptive difficulty: each time the player loses, the reaction window becomes easier (Boshi waits slightly longer) because reaction time and input lag can make fixed-timing challenges inaccessible on some displays/controllers.

Kaze frames much of his ROM-hack work as experimentation and skill-building: he intentionally made many linear levels in earlier projects to learn, and he prototypes by placing every available actor in a sandbox map, observing behaviors, and building puzzle idea lists from that research.

Renderer/performance remains an unresolved dependency: the “new F3DEX” path is still too slow on Kaze’s end, and he expects to debug whether it’s his integration or F3DEX itself in a future session with Sauraen.

Kaze’s dev environment/workflow notes: he sticks with Project64 1.6 for convenience (with the caveat that opening untrusted ROMs is the real risk), parallel launcher doesn’t work on his PC despite attempts (including DMs with its developer), and he’s planning to switch hardware testing from a bugged EverDrive X5 to SummerCart64.
Localization scope concern: Kaze estimates RTYI may reach ~500 dialogue boxes (vs ~170 in vanilla SM64, many repeated). He’s unsure about a German version because of the volume of text.

biobak.summary: Kaze pings Biobak for workflow/tooling help (hotkey/shortcut to quickly unpack resources), indicating Biobak provides practical pipeline guidance beyond art/level feedback.
Kaze privately shares an unrevealed collaboration sub-area with Biobak via DMs for feedback (but won’t show it publicly yet).

zeina.summary: Zeina supplied multiple character assets used this stream: the Dry Bones animation set (successfully integrated), the saloon piano player NPC model, and a cowboy Boshi with many animations for a duel sequence.
Kaze coordinates purchasing/dev hardware through Zeina (asks for the credit card to buy a SummerCart64), showing practical day-to-day overlap between home life and production logistics.

findings.summary: Aeza is collaborating with Kaze on a pair of levels; Kaze’s is a Course 14 sub-area. They plan to benefit from shared timing/attention while each builds separate content.
Sauraen is the expected debugging partner for investigating why Kaze’s new F3DEX integration is too slow (root cause not yet determined).

B-Turk prompts discussion of VS Code snippets and workflow automation; Kaze notes VS Code suddenly started showing recommendations/snippet-like suggestions again, which he expects will make at least one viewer very happy.
Chat points Kaze to a pre-assembled SummerCart64 ordering option; Kaze evaluates it as a potential replacement for EverDrive (cheaper, more functional, and likely to work reliably for his needs).

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Mario 64 has something very unique about it, and that is the physics, the movement that no other game coming after it can replicate.
memorable_quotes.context: Explains why SM64 remains worth deconstructing/remaking via ROM hacks, unlike other series where later entries replaced the appeal.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: It’s always been experimentation for me… I’m gonna learn as much from this as possible. That’s always my mindset.
memorable_quotes.context: Direct statement of his creative intent: hacking as deliberate skill-building rather than only content production.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Man, I’m good at such a specific thing. I’m probably the world champion of matching the Big Dry Bones behavior in New Super Mario Bros. games.
memorable_quotes.context: After recreating the Dry Bones crumble/bounce timing and behavior; humorous but revealing pride in precision craft.

key_stories.title: Finishing the Wild West Dry Bones enemy
key_stories.summary: Kaze integrates Zeina’s Dry Bones animations and iterates on how the enemy moves, detects the player, and transitions between states. He aims to preserve the feel of classic Dry Bones (including New Super Mario Bros.-style crumble behavior) while making it readable and fair in 3D.
key_stories.challenge: Animations and AI looked “off” due to timing/slow-motion feel, chase behavior toggled awkwardly near detection range, and the crumble interaction felt wrong when jumped on.
key_stories.process: He scales animation speed to actual movement speed, adjusts acceleration/deceleration and vision angle, adds line-of-sight plus distance hysteresis, syncs footstep SFX to animation frames, and changes crumble collision to pushable to maintain physical presence.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze declares the Dry Bones essentially done for now; remaining polish (notably crumble SFX) is deferred to end-of-project sound-bank work.
key_stories.key_quote: I think the Dry Bones is done. Looks good to me.

key_stories.title: Audio priority bug: barrels muting other sounds
key_stories.summary: While adding footsteps and testing the Wild West set, Kaze discovers certain barrel sounds are effectively muting other important audio feedback. He treats it as a mixing/priority configuration problem rather than a content problem.
key_stories.challenge: A barrel landing sound was high-priority and caused other sounds (like footsteps) to drop out, making the scene feel broken/quiet.
key_stories.process: He locates the sound action responsible (Wild West barrel/world spawner), creates a new sound entry for the barrel, and lowers its priority and adjusts falloff so it no longer dominates the mix.
key_stories.outcome: Footsteps and ambient movement sounds become audible again and the barrel sound stops clobbering the mix.

key_stories.title: Designing the cowboy Boshi quick-draw duel (with accessibility in mind)
key_stories.summary: Kaze lays out a dueling minigame structure and begins drafting cowboy-flavored dialogue for Boshi’s personality (arrogant/angsty/edgy). He explicitly designs around real-world reaction time variance and input lag so the challenge won’t lock players out.
key_stories.challenge: A pure reaction-time duel can become impossible depending on the player’s reflexes and hardware latency (e.g., laggy displays/controllers).
key_stories.process: He plans a countdown plus random delay before the “go” cue, then proposes dynamic difficulty: after each loss, Boshi’s draw timing becomes more forgiving so players can eventually win.
key_stories.outcome: Clear blueprint for a memorable Wild West set-piece that can scale difficulty per player performance.
key_stories.key_quote: Every consequent loss makes him wait slightly longer… reaction time is one of those fixed things.

key_stories.title: Kaze’s actor-first puzzle/level ideation method
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains how he learned Ocarina of Time hacking by building a sandbox desert, placing every actor, and observing behaviors. He translates observations into categorized idea lists, then combines them into structured puzzles/levels.
key_stories.challenge: Figuring out what’s possible and what makes good puzzles in an unfamiliar engine/toolset without wasting time building dead-end mechanics.
key_stories.process: Systematically spawn and test every actor, document surprising interactions, then classify actors into ‘good puzzle pieces,’ ‘bad/needs work,’ and ‘easily modifiable’ sets to drive later design.
key_stories.outcome: A repeatable research method that supports his broader experimentation-first philosophy and could be a cornerstone of the documentary’s depiction of his creative process.

key_stories.title: Tooling and hardware friction shaping the workflow
key_stories.summary: Kaze describes practical constraints: he uses Project64 for convenience despite its reputation, parallel launcher won’t work on his setup even with developer help, and his EverDrive X5 is unreliable. He considers SummerCart64 as a more dependable dev/testing path.
key_stories.challenge: Emulator instability/compatibility and unreliable flashcart hardware create friction in iteration speed and testing confidence.
key_stories.process: He sticks with the tools that boot fastest and work for him (Project64), rejects repeated advice to ‘just use parallel launcher,’ and researches pre-assembled SummerCart64 options to replace EverDrive.
key_stories.outcome: Likely shift in testing workflow toward SummerCart64; highlights how mundane tooling issues can materially affect a long ROM-hack project.

open_questions.context: Kaze is building a Course 14 sub-area as part of a collaboration with Aeza, but won’t show it publicly yet; he DM’d it to Biobak for feedback.
questions: What is the concept/theme of the collaboration content, and why keep it secret until a certain reveal moment?
How did the collaboration with Aeza start, and what are the boundaries (style guides, shared mechanics, deadlines)?
How will the two levels be integrated into RTYI’s progression (optional secret, required course path, bonus world)?
What feedback did Biobak give after seeing it privately, and did it change anything?

open_questions.context: Kaze says the new F3DEX approach is still too slow on his end and he needs to debug it with Sauraen to determine whether it’s his fault or F3DEX’s.
questions: What specific scenario/level reveals the slowdown most clearly, and how big is the performance delta?
What are the suspected root causes (state changes, display list generation, RSP/RDP sync, texture loads)?
What optimizations did Kaze already implement in his fork that other repos (e.g., Hexa64) don’t have?
What would a ‘success’ outcome look like (target framerate, acceptable visual compromises)?

open_questions.topic: Sound-bank/space constraints and end-of-project audio plan
open_questions.context: Kaze defers certain sounds (e.g., Dry Bones crumble SFX) to later because sound space is “weird” and needs to be handled near the end.
questions: What are the concrete limitations (bank size, number of SFX, priority channels) driving these decisions?
How do you decide which sounds are worth budget vs cut/merged/reused?
Do you have an ‘audio finaling’ milestone planned (mix pass, priority audits, per-level sound budgets)?

open_questions.context: Kaze outlines the duel minigame and adaptive difficulty approach (longer waits after losses) to address reaction time/input lag variability.
questions: How will the random delay and ‘go’ cue be communicated visually/audio-wise to avoid ambiguity?
How will you prevent cheesing (pre-firing, buffering inputs) while keeping it fair?
What are the exact thresholds for adaptive difficulty, and how many losses until it becomes trivially beatable?
Will there be optional harder rewards (fast-draw achievement/star) for skilled players?

open_questions.context: Kaze says he doesn’t know yet whether the game will include a rideable Yoshi, but suggests he ‘kind of should’ add it.
questions: What would rideable Yoshi change mechanically (movement, combat, puzzle design) in RTYI?
Is this blocked by technical complexity, animation workload, level redesign, or just scope/time?
Would Yoshi be limited to certain levels/contexts to preserve balance and performance?

open_questions.topic: Dialogue volume, repetition strategy, and localization feasibility
open_questions.context: Kaze anticipates ~500 dialogue boxes (vs ~170 in vanilla SM64) and is unsure about a German version due to sheer text volume; he notes SM64 repeats signs to ensure players see messages.
questions: Why does RTYI need significantly more dialogue—story, tutorials, comedy, NPC density, or worldbuilding?
How will you avoid dialogue becoming intrusive (skippable, shorter boxes, optional NPC chatter)?
What’s the localization plan (community translation, tools, budgets, version parity)?
Will you adopt or reject SM64’s repetition strategy for important messages?

open_questions.topic: Zeina’s character pipeline and iteration loop
open_questions.context: This stream shows Kaze repeatedly validating Zeina’s assets in-engine, then sending them back for animation fixes or naming/organization (e.g., ‘Zayna shy voice’ filename).
questions: What does the handoff pipeline look like (file formats, naming conventions, export settings, rig standards)?
What are the most common issues when importing her rigs/skins (unweighted bones, multi-weight constraints, CI format problems)?
How do you decide when an NPC/enemy is ‘good enough’ vs needs another Zeina pass?

open_questions.context: Kaze uses Project64 for convenience; parallel launcher doesn’t work on his PC; EverDrive X5 is buggy; he plans to buy a SummerCart64.
questions: What’s your current test matrix (Project64, console, other emulators), and what bugs only appear on real hardware?
What specifically fails on the EverDrive X5 for your builds?
What do you hope SummerCart64 will change in your day-to-day iteration speed and confidence?

open_questions.topic: Course 12 Wild West structure and ‘retro section’ placement
open_questions.context: Kaze references the Wild West level (Course 12) and mentions a ‘retro section’ being done, implying a deliberate tonal/structural segmentation.
questions: What is the Wild West course’s narrative/mechanical arc, and where does the ‘retro section’ fit?
How do you balance genre parody (saloon piano, quick-draw duel) with Yoshi’s Island identity?
Which parts are core progression vs optional set-pieces/minigames?

open_questions.topic: Program pooling as a performance culprit
open_questions.context: Kaze claims a major cause of performance issues is “program pooling,” but doesn’t elaborate on what specifically is pooled or how it manifests in RTYI.
questions: What do you mean by program pooling in this context (state machines, object reuse, memory pools, display list pooling)?
Which gameplay features forced you into pooling patterns, and what tradeoffs did you accept?
Are there levels/mechanics you redesigned specifically to avoid pooling overhead?
